Aceable is an online educational platform for certification and training courses. Their main products include drivers ed and defensive driving. While fast paced, interactive content of their application is favorited by thousands of students, as every company, they are dealing with some pain points.

Table of contents

  • Preparation and Scope
  • Research
  • Information Synthesis
  • Concepts Generation
  • Interaction Vizualization
  • Ideation
  • Testing
  • Refining and Repeating

1. PREPARATION AND SCOPE

Type of the project: Team project
Role: UX/UI Designer performing the following tasks:

✓interviews ✓persona ✓user journey map ✓user flow wireframing ✓prototyping ✓user testing
Tools: Sketch
Adobe Illustrator
Adobe Photoshop
InVision
Maze

2. RESEARCH

PROBLEM STATEMENT
Ater examining existing data from Customer Experience department, we found out that PTDE students don’t realise they can download and print their certificates from within their account and that they can sign in and do so even after they finish the course, as their access is not suspended.

SWOT ANALYSIS

WHY IS THIS IMPORTANT?

Accessing and printing certificates is crucial to students success in getting the permit and license.
Leads to unnecessary contacts for CX that student’s have the power to resolve quickly on their own.
Leads to a lot unnecessary frustration of contacts for students.

WHY THIS PROBLEM OCCURS? HOW DOES IT LOOK LIKE CURRENTLY?

1
Picture with partying people is not adequate and takes a lot of space in email.
2
The link to certificite isn’t very visible. No information about having access to it anytime.
The picture should be more professional/official, the text should too. It doesn’t feel like I just finished a major milestone. It feels like it’s belittling me.
The above statements were created by our team after seeing current screens within the application. We decided to confront our assumptions with group of 4 teenagers. We received following feedback:
1
Currently students can find their certificates on the homepage or after clicking home icon. It’s not intuitive for many of them.
2
“View License Certificate” on the dashboard is misleading. Student is not aware which certificate to choose from.

Surveys

Whiteboarding and brainstorming

After thorough analysis of the current user flow and getting feedback from the interviewees, we started brainstorming and thinking about potential solutions:

3. INFORMATION SYNTHESIS

The above statements were created by our team after seeing current screens within the application. We decided to confront our assumptions with group of 4 teenagers. We received following feedback:

Main goals for redesign:

Proto Personas

User Persona

We created our persona basing on indept research - the articles and statistics about young people who are between 15-17 years old ( Generation Z) and initial interviews with group of teenagers. Our persona reflects the behavior and motivations of the users we were interviewing.

Empathy Map

The next deliverable which gave us deep understanding of social behavior of our targeted audience was empathy map. We were observing or interviewees during the initial meeting, were listening to their responses, noticing their reactions. It helped us a lot with creating a map that reflets the needs and frustations of the representants of young generation.

4. CONCEPTS GENERATION

User Journey Map

Whiteboarding and creating user journey map helped us with identifying painful parts of the process and thinking about the opportunities. It was crucial for us to invision the whole process, to see where exactly the problem starts, in which stage of the process and what’s the best bay to adress the user needs.

Findings and ideas how to solve the problem

Calendar feature
“View Certificate” on the dashboard isn’t very visible. Easily missed or glossed over
Quick filters ( icons)
Send push notification that leads them to where the certificate lives in the account
Decluttered interface
Create a designated icon in the menu that leads to earned certificates
Help / Support
Create a designated icon in the menu that leads to earned certificates
Wishlist
Change the color of the icon once the certificate is received
Subscriptions & Orders
Make it clear that students can download and print from their account anytime
Highlighting features
Use the Ace image in the notifications and emails
Small and local businesses
Use the Ace image in the notifications and emails

5. INTERACTION VISUALIZATION

After creating maps and graphs and thinking through our strategy, it was the highest time to start puttting our ideas in the shapes of buttons, icons and other UI elemnts and create first wierframes.

Low fidelity paper wireframes

We met with test participants one at a time and gave them tasks to perform, asking them to vocalize their thoughts as they attempted tasks such as going through the user flow, finding particular elements, showing us, where would they lokk for their certificates etc.

Wireframes testing findings

- Overall users liked the wireframes
- In the emails users preferred either icons only or bold text only, but not both. But they prefer just bold text.
- Users would keep the title of the email as not a link, would only have one link to the certificate because it might generate multiple copies.
- The wording on the emails felt “pandering and not endearing” they preferred it to say “Congratulations” or something more formal/serious.
- No need for icons on the email.
- They don’t mind having 2 links to download (one in the title, one in the body) but that it should be made clear it will download something, otherwise they wouldn’t like it.
- They like the Ace drawing.
- They would have the links next to the icons, not underneath header text.
- They like the icons.

Insights

I would keep the title of the email as not a link, would only have one link to the certificate because it might generate multiple copies.
I’d like to see a certificate button on the nav bar, but gold colored.

6. IDEATION

Style Guide

Hi fidelity prototype

1
Notification which says what students can do and reminds about diving back into the course
2
Email with less amout of steps and highlighted most important links
3
Pop-up with short instructions and reminder about the opportunity of having access to certs anytime
4
Notification which says what students can do and reminds about diving back into the course
5
Email with less amout of steps and highlighted most important links
6
Screen with dedicated nav icon for certificates
7
Screen with dedicated nav icon for certificates
8
Pop-up with short instructions and reminder about the opportunity of having access to certs anytime
9

10
Last screen which appears when student is printing the certificate
11
Notification which says what students can do and reminds about diving back into the course
12
Email with less amout of steps and highlighted most important links
13
Screen with dedicated nav icon for certificates
14
Screen with dedicated nav icon for certificates
15
Pop-up with short instructions and reminder about the opportunity of having access to certs anytime
16
Screen with miniature of certificate and two options ( download or print)
17
Last screen which appears when student is printing the certificate
Hi-fidelity prototype was created after couple of iterations. We utylized users feedback and changed the parts in the previous versions of our wireframes, which weren’t intuitive / effective enough. in the final version of the prototype we wanted to make sure that usres are not taking any unnecesarry steps towards getting access to desired certificates.

7. TESTING

Usability testing with MAZE

We tested our hi-fidelity prototypes using a Maze tool with 5 users who were between 15-17 yo. It helped us visualize the hitmaps, where users were clicking and if they flow was stereamlined enough. As we collected the results we found out that the average time to complete the task was 12 minutes and a misclick rate only 12 %. One of the users left the following feedback:
Simple, fast and straight to the point. It’s not at all confusing and allows the user to get their certificate quickly.

8. REFINING AND REPEATING

Conclusions

We found out that understanding the expectations of a generation that grew up with technology and the internet isn’t easy. We were very glad that our research wasn’t based just on the articles and statistics. We reached out to a group of teenagers who told us, how the user experience look like from their point of view. We were suprised many times during our interviews and usability testing. Deep understanding of teens motivations and needs helped us with designing solutions that could solve one of the Aceable’s problems.
